goal.en: Fredric Jameson argues in The Political Unconscious for the political interpretation as the primary method for understanding literature as a “socially symbolic act,” “as the absolute horizon of all reading and all interpretation.” This course studies the political interpretation of narrative cinema in order to understand the socio-historical meanings of films from Mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
goal.ch: 電影與政治從電影誕生那天起便從未分割。本課程以中國大陸、香港和臺灣的電影爲例，研究從 20 世紀初到當代的流動影像與政治之間的複雜關係。

content.en:
We will examine issues including but not limited to history and dissidence; urban vs. rural differences; gender and sexual politics; socialist, colonial, and cold war modernities. We will examine cinema as a social and signifying practice, and study how fantasies, desires, anxieties, ethics and values concerning power relations and social change have been projected, articulated, reformulated and received on and off screen across different times and communities.
In order to enable and facilitate discussion in class, it is highly preferable for students seriously interested in taking this course to leave open Wed. afternoons to attend additional screenings. Please note that some of the films may not have English subtitles.
content.ch: 我們將通過閱讀大量電影與論述，探討包括恐華/恐共症候；宣傳、歷史和異議；城鄉矛盾；性/別；社會主義、殖民地和冷戰現代性等議題。我們將試圖瞭解在不同時代和政治文化背景下，對權力關係和社會變革的想像、欲望、焦慮、倫理和價值觀是如何通過銀幕內外的政治化和/或去政治化過程被投射、重新表述、轉化和認受。由於課堂上需要討論大量台灣難以看到的電影和論述作品，認真欲修讀本課的學生需要在每週三下午預留時間，共同參與課外放映。

textbook.en: Fredric Jameson (1981) The Political Unconscious: Narrative as a Socially Symbolic Act. Ithaca: Cornell University Press. Stuart Hall (ed.) (1997) Representation: Cultural Representations and Signifying Practices. London: Sage and Open University. Christopher Rea (2006) Chinese Film Classics, 1922–1949. New York: Columbia University Press, 2021. Zhang Zhen (2006) An Amorous History of the Silver Screen: Shanghai Cinema, 1896-1937. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
textbook.ch: 李鎮 (2020)《因為有光——電影文本研究》，上海：三聯書店。 周星、張燕編(2020)《亞洲電影的現實表達與文化想像》，北京：中央編譯出版社。

grading.en: MUST COME TO FIRST CLASS IN ORDER TO ENROLL. THERE WILL BE ADDITIONAL SCREENINGS IN WED AFTERNOONS. 1. Continuous assessment 35％ Attendance in all classes. Completion of required readings, assignments and active participation in class discussion and presentation. In-class discussion is an essential component in grading and evaluating students’ learning and performance. Students are required to reflect on their own learning progress through weekly screenings and discussions. 2. Individual presentation on assigned readings 30％ Weekly-scheduled presentation that encourages critical reading, peer-learning and presentation skills. 3. Final paper with proposal and draft 35％ A term paper is required from each student to develop her/his own analysis and independent research skills. This paper will be shared amongst all students for peer critique and learning. *You must complete all assignments and attend all screenings to pass this course.
